questions.text: A patient has this pulse on examination.What is the likely cause
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

This pulse is showing regular alteration of pulse amplitude seen in LV systolic failure.One of the cause is dilated cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: A Patient of acute MI developed complete heart block. What will be the clinical sign in JVP?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Causes of cannon a wave in JVP include- junctional rhythm,complete heart block(AV dissociation) and PSVT.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with diffuse apex beat
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Severe LV dysfunction causes diffuse apex beat-area more than 2.5 cm2.Other options are causes of absent apex beat

choices.text: Mixed aortic valve disease (aortic stenosis and aortic regurgitation)

questions.text: The causes of continuous murmur include all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The continuous murmur is characterized by being heard in both systole and diastole with peak around S 2.The pitch should be similar.This is different from a systolic and diastolic murmur, as noted in mixed aortic valve disease. In that case, one will hear a harsh, diamond-shaped systolic murmur, a second heart sound (which might be single), and a diastolic murmur. These murmurs will have two distinctly different pitches.
The causes of continuous murmur- 
•    Arteriovenous fistulas 
•    Patent ductus arteriosus 
•    Ruptured sinus of Valsalva aneurysm, 
•    Coronary fistula, 
•    Severe coarctation of the aorta
•    Venous hum

questions.text: All of the following physical examination findings would suggest a diagnosis of aortic regurgitation except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Bisferiens pulse- 2 peaks in systole is seen in severe AR. The murmur of aortic regurgitation is a high-pitched early diastolic. A mid-diastolic - the Austin-Flint murmur, may be heard in aortic regurgitation when an eccentric jet hits the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve, causing it to reverberate and generating the apical rumble.Late systolic murmur is seen in Mitral valve prolapse.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a history of diabetes, coronary artery disease (CAD), and hypertension has now developed diabetic nephropathy. Which of the following drug will be useful for managing hypertension?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

ACE inhibitors and ARBs have demonstrated a significant renal protective effect in the diabetic patient with nephropathy. Thiazide can impair diabetes control and beta blocker masks hypoglycemic awareness.

questions.text: Which of the following cardiac lesions has the highest risk of developing endocarditis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

A MR is considered a relatively high-risk lesion for infective endocarditis. Mitral valve prolapse with regurgitation, asymmetric septal hypertrophy, and pure mitral stenosis are considered an intermediate risk. Atrial septal defects of the secundum type are considered low risk

questions.text: A 65 year old man presents with a 4-week history of fever, general malaise and lethargy. He attends the emergency department and has blood cultures taken and he undergoes an echocardiogram, which shows a mass on his mitral valve. Conjunctival petechiae and tender finger tips are noted. What is the most likely organism that will be grown from his blood cultures?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

This patient has subacute IE(presentation > 2 weeks).Viridans streptococci is the most common cause of sub acute endocarditis .Staphylococcus aureus is the most common organism from hospital acquired IE.Coagulase negative staphylococcus is the most common to infect prosthetic valves within one year and after one year its streptococcus viridans.

questions.text: CHF is associated with increase in all the following except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

There is dilutional hyponatremia in CHF due to fluid retention. BNP is released from stretched ventricle. Nor epinephrine and TNF alpha are  released due to acute stress.

questions.text: All of the following are beneficial treatment for Prinzmetal angina except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Nitrate relieves variant angina attacks within minutes. CCBs are very effective in preventing attacks of variant angina; CCB are used for maintenance. There is no documented role for beta-blockers.

questions.text: Identify the wall of myocardial infarction in this ECG
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

There is ST elevation in II,III and aVF s/o inferior wall MI.

questions.text: A 56 year old man presents with sudden onset of chest pain radiating down his left arm, ST segment depression of the ECG as shown in the figure and elevated plasma troponin concentration . Which of the following treatments is not given?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Non-ST segment myocardial infarction is normally initially managed with dual antiplatelet therapy (e.g. aspirin and ticagrelor), and an antithrombotic agent (e.g. fondaparinux or enoxaparin). β-Blockade is often used as prophylaxis against angina and arrhythmias. Intravenous tPA is a treatment for acute ST elevation myocardial infarction and has not been shown to improve outcome in patients with non-ST segment elevation myocardial infarction. Indeed, patients with ST segment depression have a worse outcome with thrombolytic therapy.

choices.text: Wenckebach (Mobitz type I) second-degree AV block
Mobitz type II second degree block

questions.text: Which conduction abnormality does this show?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

In Mobitz type II second-degree AV block, most P waves conduct normally to the ventricles and are associated with a QRS complex. Some P waves do not conduct and there is no preceding increase in the P–R interval before the blocked P wave. This reflects block in the His–Purkinje system where conduction is ‘all-or-nothing’. In contrast, Mobitz type I second-degree AV block is characterised by progressive lengthening of the P–R interval block.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman is seen in the emergency department after sudden onset of palpitations. Her heart rate is 17 bpm and blood pressure is 98/56 mmHg with normal oxygen saturation. On physical examination there is tachycardia but is otherwise normal. ECG done is shown in the figure. Which of the following is the most appropriate first step to manage her tachycardia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Patient has PSVT as assessed by narrow complex tachycardia without P waves. Patient is hemodynamically stable hence first carotid massage will be given.

questions.text: This ecg is seen in
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

There is alteration in QRS amplitude known as electrical alternans typical seen in massive pericardial effusion/tamponade.

choices.text: Intravenous bolus dose of magnesium sulphate

questions.text: A patient develops these ECG changes  after an overdose of sotalol. Which one is NOT likely to be helpful in the management of this situation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

These are all useful interventions for torsades de pointes except procainamide. Magnesium sulphate reduces the risk of torsades without affecting the QT interval and is first-line treatment. Isoproterenol and pacing increase the underlying ventricular rate and reduce the risk of recurrence, as torsades is a bradycardia-dependent arrhythmia, although they are infrequently needed. Hypokalaemia worsens the risk of torsades, so correction is beneficial. Procainamide is a class Ia anti-dysrhythmic drug that further prolongs ventricular repolarisation and would worsen the risk of torsades.

questions.text: Which is not a feature of Sydenham’s chorea
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Abnormal movements decreases during sleep in Sydenham’s chorea.It’s a late manifestation of rheumatic fever.

questions.text: Which of the following treatments is known to reduce risk of sudden death in patients with dilated cardiomyopathy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Loop diuretics have no effect on mortality in patients with cardiac failure. Rate-limiting calcium channel blockers such as diltiazem and verapamil are usually avoided, as they have a negative inotropic effect, which may aggravate cardiac failure. Aspirin and percutaneous coronary intervention are treatments for coronary artery disease, not cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is known to be effective in preventing stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Antiplatelet drugs are no longer recommended for stroke prevention in atrial fibrillation, although they are effective at preventing stroke due to carotid vascular disease. Amiodarone and β-blockers can help prevent atrial fibrillation episodes but are not known to reduce stroke risk. Apixaban is an oral factor Xa inhibitor, which has been shown in large-scale clinical trials to be effective at preventing stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation and moderate-to high stroke risk

questions.text: A patient admitted to the emergency department with severe chest pain and ST segment deviation suddenly collapses and is found not to be breathing or have a pulse.  A cardiac arrest call is made. What is the most likely cause of his collapse?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Ventricular fibrillation is an early complication  of acute myocardial infarction and is the  leading preventable cause of death.

choices.text: New widespread ST elevation or PR depression on ECG

questions.text: Which of the following findings is not a diagnostic criterion for acute pericarditis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Acute pericarditis is usually characterized by sharp retrosternal pain that is aggravated by lying down and relieved by sitting up; its onset is often heralded by a prodrome of fever, malaise, and myalgia. The most specific physical sign can be the presence of a pericardial friction rub , which is identifiable in no more than a third of cases. Within a few hours of the onset of chest pain, typical ECG changes include ST-segment elevations and depression of the PR segment (except in lead aVR), which can persist for hours or days.Electric alternans seen in pericardial effusion.

questions.text: All are features of ECG changes of hyperkalemia except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hyperkalemia leads to Tall T wave, ST elevation, wide QRS and absent P wave in ECG.Prolong QT interval seen in hypokalemia.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT associated with aortic regurgitation
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Williams syndrome is associated with aortic stenosis.

The causes of AR are-

questions.text: A 63 year old patient presented to you with 2 episodes of syncope in last 2 weeks while climbing up the stairs.His vitals are stable.You noted ejection systolic murmur at right second intercostal space radiating to carotids.What will be the most appropriate next line investigation
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


The clinical features are suggestive of aortic stenosis.The next line investigation will be echocardiogram.

choices.text: A disease of the myocardium characterised by chamber enlargement and thinning of the left and right ventricular walls
A disease of the myocardium characterised by disproportionate thickening of the interventricular septum
A disease of the myocardium characterised by infiltration of myocardial tissue resulting in restricted contraction and relaxation
Isolated dilatation of the right ventricle, causing ventricular tachycardia

questions.text: Which of the following best describes dilated cardiomyopathy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Dilated cardiomyopathy is characterised by dilatation of the atria and ventricles, and thinning of ventricular walls. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy causes disproportionate thickening of myocardium, particularly the interventricular septum. Myocardial infiltration (e.g. with amyloid protein) can cause restrictive cardiomyopathy, which does not cause cardiac dilatation but does restrict myocardial contraction and relaxation.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents with dyspnea and dizziness. On examination, second heart sound splits more with inspiration. A fourth heart sound is present, there is diamond-shaped systolic murmur at the base which increases in intensity with the Valsalva maneuver and with standing. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Systolic murmur that becomes louder with manoeuvres that decrease preload, a cardinal physical examination finding present in hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy. Dilated cardiomyopathy can present with a third heart sound and murmurs of mitral and tricuspid regurgitation.

questions.text: Which of the following features regarding restrictive cardiomyopathy is not true
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Restrictive CMP is characterised by
•    Diastolic dysfunction
•    Biatrial enlargement
•    Clinical features resemble constrictive pericarditis

questions.text: Which of the following Is the most appropriate next step in management of the patient of acute decompensated heart failure with pulmonary edema?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
 
Acute management of ADHF includes supplemental oxygen and intravenous loop diuretics.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with a history of cigarette smoking presents with accelerating anginal chest pain. On initial evaluation, his troponin T is normal, and an electrocardiogram demonstrates T-wave inversions in leads I and aVL. In addition to aspirin, beta blocker, LMWH, nitrate, you will prescribe:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

For this patient with unstable angina managed medically, clopidogrel should be added to aspirin therapy for 12 months, assuming there is not a high risk of bleeding. Ranolazine is anti- ischemic therapies that can improve anginal symptoms but have no effect on cardiovascular mortality. There is no role for fish oil in managing unstable angina.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presents with 30 minutes of palpitations. Her symptoms began abruptly. A physical examination reveals a tachycardic, regular heart rhythm and blood pressure of 132/82 mm Hg and is otherwise normal. An ECG is shown in Figure. 
 
Carotid sinus pressure fails to terminate the arrhythmia. The next best step in management is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Electrocardiogram demonstrates a narrow complex regular tachycardia at approximately 150 beats per minute suggestive of PSVT. Vagal manoeuvres were an appropriate first step but were unsuccessful. Adenosine should be administered, which will be both diagnostic and possibly therapeutic by terminating AV node–dependent arrhythmias (AVNRT and AVRT) here is no need for DC cardioversion, because this patient is hemodynamically stable. Amiodarone is not indicated in this case.

questions.text: The given ECG represents which arrythmia
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Wide QRS with rate of 100-250/min is ventricular tachycardia.Wide QRS with rate > 250/min is ventricular flutter.Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia is Torsades de pointes.Choatic pattern of QRS with no definitive complexes is ventricular fibrillation.

questions.text: All the following ECG changes are due to digoxin except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Digoxin causes all type of AV block except Mobitz type II second degree AV block.Other ECG changes are ventricular ectopics, bigeminy rhythm and bidirectional ventricular tachycardia.

questions.text: Identify the pattern in the given ECG
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

In lead V5 or V6 absence of initial q waves,wide QRS and M pattern of QRS are suggestive of LBBB>

choices.text: Each P will be followed by QRS

questions.text: The electrocardiogram  shows Wenckebach’s type atrioventricular (AV) block. Which of the following are you most likely to see on the ECG?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Wenckebach, or type I second-degree AV block, is characterized on ECG by progressive lengthening of the PR interval until there is a nonconducted P wave.

questions.text: Identify the auscultation area marked as number 3 in the diagram.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The area no. 1 is aortic area,2 is pulmonary area,4 is tricuspid area and no. 5 is apex.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with dyspnea, chest pain and light-headed on exertion. O/E-Pulse is slow rising with late peak. On auscultation systolic murmur, crescendo-decrescendo in nature heard best in the second right intercostal area. What is the cause of these clinical findings
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The classical symptoms of aortic stenosis are dyspnea + angina+ exertional syncope. The causes of AS are age related calcification, atherosclerosis (given in the question), RHD and bicuspid aortic valve. The murmur of AS is best heard at second right intercostal space (aortic area) and is ejection systolic (crescendo-decrescendo murmur).AR is early diastolic murmur, MS produces mid diastolic murmur and MR have pansystolic murmur.

questions.text: For a patient with ST elevation MI what is the ideal door to balloon time in a PCI capable centre.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The various time intervals in STEMI are
•    Door to balloon time < 90 min
•    Symptom onset for PCI < 24 hrs
•    Door to needle time < 30 min
•    Symptom onset for thrombolysis < 12 hrs
•    Shifting to PCI if delay in PCI < 120 min

questions.text: Which of the following is the physical finding in cardiac tamponade?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Cardiac tamponade presents as classical triad of low BP,neck vein distension and soft heart sounds. Pulsus paradoxus is common and apex beat is non localised.

questions.text: A 14 year old boy presented with acute rheumatic fever with evidence of carditis. With supportive treatment he improved. Now you are discharging patient on penicillin prophylaxis. He should be receiving prophylaxis till he is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Duration of secondary prophylaxis is as follows-

questions.text: A 40 year old male has developed high grade fever of 104 F with pulse rate of 100/min. His baseline pulse used to be 80/min. All the following can be the causes except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Causes of relative bradycardia
•    Typhoid fever
•    Factitious fever
•    Brucella
•    Legionella
•    Viral fevers
